statement.text: Manual lymph drainage (MLD) is a specialized gentle massage technique using light pressure and rhythmic movements to enhance lymphatic flow, redirect lymph to functioning pathways, and reduce edema in patients with lymphedema.

explanation.intuition: Think of MLD as gently pushing fluid through a network of tiny tubes. Unlike regular massage which pushes on muscles, MLD uses very light pressure to stretch the skin and stimulate the lymphatic vessels just beneath it. The key is moving fluid from congested areas toward areas that can still drain normally.
explanation.key_insight: MLD alone has limited evidence, but when combined with compression bandaging as part of Complete Decongestive Therapy (CDT), it is highly effective. The sequence is critical: always clear the trunk first to 'make room' for fluid from the limb.

technique.pressure: Light (30-40 mmHg) - just enough to stretch the skin
technique.sequence: Proximal to distal - trunk clearing, then proximal limb, then distal

training_schools.Vodder: Original European technique, emphasis on light pressure

evidence.with_compression: Strong evidence when combined with compression as CDT

sources.reference: Ezzo J et al. Manual lymphatic drainage for lymphedema following breast cancer treatment. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2015;(5):CD003475
International Society of Lymphology. Consensus Document on Lymphedema. Lymphology. 2020;53(1):3-19

learning_objectives: Describe the technique of manual lymph drainage
Understand the role of MLD in complete decongestive therapy
Recognize the importance of proper training
clinical_pearls: MLD uses VERY light pressure - heavy massage is counterproductive
Always clear the TRUNK first before treating the limb
MLD alone has limited evidence - combine with compression
Self-MLD techniques help patients maintain results at home
Contraindicated in acute infection, DVT, or active malignancy
